<section class="course-item" data-cats="replication">
<h3>Computational Economics (*Fall 2024*)</h3>
<div class="course-note">Here’s a brief note between the labels and the description.</div>
<div class="course-tags">
  <span class="course-tag">Replication package</span>
</div>

Together with [CHAMBON Lionel](https://lionelchambon.github.io/) and [GUGELMO CAVALHEIRO DIAS Paulo](https://www.paulogcd.com/), we translated the replication package of Monge-Naranjo, Alexander, Juan M. Sanchez, and Raul Santaeulalia-Llopis, "Natural Resources and Global Misallocation" (AEJ Macroeconomics 11:2, 2019) from Stata to Julia. This was done for the [Computational Economics](https://floswald.github.io/NumericalMethods/) class taught by [Florian Oswald](https://floswald.github.io/) at Sciences Po. We obtained the grade of 19/20 for this work.

You can find our package documentation and work repository here: [Replication package of Monge-Naranjo et al., 2019, in Julia](https://www.paulogcd.com/Replication_Monge_et_al_2019.jl/dev/).
</section>

<section class="course-item" data-cats="presentation referee">
<h3>Topics in Public and Environmental Economics (*Fall 2024*)</h3>
<div class="course-tags">
  <span class="course-tag">Paper presentation</span>
  <span class="course-tag">Referee report</span>
</div>
This is a group presentation done during the fall semester of 2024-2025 for the class taught by [Stefan Pollinger](https://www.stefanpollinger.com/). We presented the working paper of Chancel and Rehm on the Carbon Footprint of Capital. The link sends you to our slides and a detailed summary of the article (here is the [latest version of the paper](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/8jsi7pgno80xlhhjsu3zc/CarbonCapital2023ChancelRehm.pdf?rlkey=nu70bve6k1ofmqz2zpttox9gh&e=1)). The referee report was written individually. These works combined received the grade of 16/20.

You can find our dedicated project website [here](https://www.paulogcd.com/TPEE_Presentation/) and my referee report [here](docs/pdf/COMPERAT.Etienne_referee-report_Chancel-and-Rehm.pdf).
</section>

<section class="course-item" data-cats="presentation">
<h3>Macroeconomics 2 (*Spring 2024*)</h3>
<div class="course-tags">
  <span class="course-tag">Paper presentation</span>
</div>
This is a group presentation done in the spring semester of 2024 for the "Macroeconomics 2" class taught by [Jean Barthelemy](https://sites.google.com/site/jeanbarthelemyeconomist/home) (Banque de France) that consisted in a one-hour presentation of the paper "Bank runs, Deposit Insurance, and Liquidity," by Douglas W. Diamond and Philip H. Dybvig (2020). We received the grade of 19/20 for this presentation.

You can find our presentation here: [Macroeconomics Group Presentation about the Diamond Dybvig model of Bank Runs](docs/pdf/macro_pre.pdf).
</section>

<section class="course-item" data-cats="research">
<h3>Microeconomics 2 (*Spring 2024*)</h3>
<div class="course-note">
<em>With Paul Farnault, Jean Fontalirand, and Nathanaël Soulage<em>

Course taught by [Emeric Henry](https://sites.google.com/site/emericmlhenry/home) (Sciences Po)</div>
<div class="course-tags">
  <span class="course-tag">Research project</span>
</div>
For this group research project, we developed and analyzed a game-theoretic model of class-attendance decisions, formulating student behavior as strategic interaction under workload constraints. The project involved constructing: a baseline simultaneous-move game with heterogeneous student types and Bayesian Nash equilibria,
a dynamic signaling extension with Perfect Bayesian Equilibria across periods, and
a teacher–student extension where a workload-setting instructor solves an optimization problem anticipating equilibrium attendance responses.

The [report](docs/pdf/Micro_Group_Project.pdf). includes full model specification, equilibrium derivations, and comparative statics on workload, beliefs, and incentives.

</section>

<section class="course-item" data-cats="research">
<h3>Contemporary Theories of Political Economy (*Fall 2022*)</h3>
<div class="course-note">Course taught by [Steven K. Vogel](https://polisci.berkeley.edu/people/person/steven-vogel) (UC Berkeley)</div>
<div class="course-tags">
  <span class="course-tag">Research project</span>
</div>
For this [theory paper](docs/pdf/polecon_flows.pdf) assignment, I wrote a comparative political-economy paper examining Fernand Braudel’s longue-durée analysis of “économie-monde” and David Harvey’s theory of capital circulation, focusing on how both frameworks integrate geography into the study of capitalism. The paper develops an analytical connection between Braudel’s emphasis on control of trade infrastructures and Harvey’s concepts of the capital fix and spatial fix, using the Belt and Road Initiative as an illustrative case of territorial domination through the management of capital flows

</section>

<script>
(function() {
  const items = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.course-item'));
  const buttons = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.cat-filter'));

  function applyFilter(cat) {
    items.forEach(item => {
      const cats = (item.dataset.cats || '').split(/\s+/).filter(Boolean);
      const match = cat === 'all' || cats.includes(cat);
      item.style.display = match ? '' : 'none';
    });
    buttons.forEach(btn => {
      btn.classList.toggle('active', btn.dataset.cat === cat);
    });
  }

  buttons.forEach(btn => {
    btn.addEventListener('click', (e) => {
      e.preventDefault();
      applyFilter(btn.dataset.cat);
    });
  });

  applyFilter('all');
})();
</script>
